Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI studies mathematical problems motivated by quantum mechanics and wave propagation. His central interest is the study of scattering resonances. These appear in many guises: as poles of Green functions, zeros of zeta functions or modes of decay and oscillation of waves, and the setting of their study ranges from geometry and automorphic forms, to microelectromechanical systems in engineering. The PI searches unifying themes and investigates specific cases. Special recent focus has been chaotic scattering and the relation between objects in thermodynamic formalism and the distribution of quantum resonances.

Waves encountered in experimental and theoretical studies have rates of oscillations and rates of decay. These two properties can be described by a single complex number with the real part corresponding to the rate of oscillations, and the imaginary part, to the rate of decay. In turn, these numbers appear as zeros of natural mathematical objects. In quantum mechanics, particles are described by wave functions, and waves with decay correspond to unstable particles. Classical/quantum correspondence suggests some subtle interplay between "classical" properties of the system and properties of waves. The PI investigates this in many settings, in particular when chaotic behaviour is present on the classical level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In most observed phenomena waves possess frequencies of oscillation and rates of decay -- a standard example is  "a bell sounding its last dying notes". These frequencies and rates of decay are properties of the medium or the scatterer and not of position and direction. They are important in diverse situations, ranging from MEMS (microelectromechnical systems) to black holes. In pure mathematics they appear as zeros of the Riemann zeta function (the famous Riemann hypothesis can be rephrased as saying that the rates of decay of waves on a modular surface are all equal) and of various other zeta functions, in particular the ones appearing in chaotic dynamics. 

The PI, his collaborators and students study the properties of these frequencies and rates of decay (which can be unified as complex numbers called resonances or scattering poles). We made significant progress on the understanding of the relation between the properties of the medium/scatterer and the distribution of resonances. The key is the particle/wave (classical/quantum) correspondence: the nature of the trajectories of particles (classical motion) determines asymptotic features of frequencies and rates of decay of waves (quantum motion). For instance in some geometric situations (normally hyperbolic trapping) we were able to provide precise asymptotic rates of decay. One could say we go from "classical to quantum". 

One of the new developments is reversing this strategy in the setting of chaotic dynamics. By "going from classical to quantum and back" we were able to introduce new techniques in chaotic dynamics. For instance, we could show that modes of correlations (the Pollicott--Ruelle resonances) for chaotic flows are stable when small randomness (Brownian motion) is added (see the second figure). That strengthens the case for physical relevance of these much studied objects.

We continue this research by looking for general principles and by studying specific cases in detail. The first figure shows the plot of response of the system at given frequency (a Fourier transform of measurements of waves in time): the response may depend on the location of measurements but its features are determined by resonances (the complex numbers) which depend on only on the system.
